{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox person |name = Stephen Hillenburg |image = Stephen Hillenburg by Carlos Cazurro.jpg |alt = A photograph of a middle-aged man in a jacket standing and holding a book |caption = Hillenburg, holding the [[Bible (screenwriting)|bible]] for ''SpongeBob SquarePants'', in 2011 |birth_name = Stephen McDannell Hillenburg |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1961|08|21}} |birth_place = [[Lawton, Oklahoma]], United States |education = {{plainlist| *[[Humboldt State University]] ([[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]],{{nbsp}}1984) *[[California Institute of the Arts]] ([[Master of Fine Arts|M.F.A.]],{{nbsp}}1992) }} |years_active = 1984{{ndash}}present |occupation = {{Hlist|Cartoonist|animator|director|producer|writer}} |notable_works = ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]'' |home_town = [[Anaheim, California]], U.S. |spouse = Karen Hillenburg |children = 1 |module = {{Infobox scientist |embed = yes |field = [[Marine biology]] |workplaces = [[Ocean Institute|Orange County Marine Institute]] |influences = [[Jacques Cousteau]] }} |signature = Stephen Hillenburg signature.svg }} '''Stephen McDannell Hillenburg'''<ref name="Veromi">{{cite web|url=http://www.veromi.net/Summary.asp?fn=Stephen&mn=&ln=Hillenburg&dobmm=08&dobdd=21&doby=1961&city=&state=&age=&vw=&Search=&Input=&x=0&y=0|title=People Search: Hillenburg, Stephen|date=April 5, 2010|publisher=Veromi|accessdate=April 5, 2010|subscription=yes|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131220122937/http://www.veromi.net/Summary.asp?fn=Stephen&mn=&ln=Hillenburg&dobmm=08&dobdd=21&doby=1961&city=&state=&age=&vw=&Search=&Input=&x=0&y=0|archivedate=December 20, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> (born August{{nbsp}}21, 1961) is an American cartoonist, [[animator]], and former [[List of marine biologists|marine biologist]]. He is the creator of the [[Nickelodeon]] television series ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]'' (1999{{ndash}}), which he has also directed, produced, and written. It has gone on to become one of the [[List of longest-running United States television series|longest-running American television series]] as well as the highest-rated show ever to air on Nickelodeon.
Born in [[Lawton, Oklahoma]] and raised in [[Anaheim, California]], Hillenburg became fascinated with the ocean as a child and developed an interest in art. He started his professional career in 1984, instructing marine biology, at the [[Ocean Institute|Orange County Marine Institute]], where he wrote ''The Intertidal Zone'', an informative comic book about [[tide pool|tide-pool]] animals, which he used to educate his students. In 1989, two years after leaving teaching, Hillenburg enrolled at the [[California Institute of the Arts]] to pursue a career in animation. He was later offered a job on the Nickelodeon animated television series ''[[Rocko's Modern Life]]'' (1993{{ndash}}1996) after his success with short films ''The Green Beret'' and ''Wormholes'' (both 1992), which he made while studying animation.
In 1994, Hillenburg began developing ''The Intertidal Zone'' characters and concepts for what became ''SpongeBob SquarePants''. The show premiered in 1999 and has aired since then. He also directed ''[[The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie]]'' (2004), which he originally intended to be the [[series finale]]. However, Nickelodeon wanted to produce more episodes, so Hillenburg resigned as the [[showrunner]]. He went back to making short films, with ''Hollywood Blvd., USA'' (2013). In 2015, ''[[The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water]]'' premiered; the sequel to the 2004 film, it marked Hillenburg's return to the show, after he co-wrote the story.
Besides his two [[Emmy Award]]s and six [[Annie Award]]s for ''SpongeBob SquarePants'', Hillenburg has also received other recognition, such as an accolade from [[Heal the Bay]] for his efforts on elevating marine life awareness, and the [[National Cartoonists Society Division Awards#Television Animation Award|Television Animation Award]] from the [[National Cartoonists Society]]. Despite this, he has been involved in public controversies, including one that centered on speculation over the [[SpongeBob SquarePants (character)|SpongeBob]] character's intended sexual orientation, and a lawsuit that was filed against him. Hillenburg has been diagnosed with [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]] (ALS) in 2017, but stated he would continue to work on his show.
==Early life and education== Stephen Hillenburg was born on August{{nbsp}}21, 1961, at [[Fort Sill]],<ref name="Abbey, p. 120">{{harvnb|Abbey|2004|p=120}}</ref><ref name="Lenburg, p. 140">{{harvnb|Lenburg|2006|p=140}}</ref><ref name="Current Biography">{{Cite journal|author=K.E.D.|title=Cover Biography for April 2003|url=http://www.hwwilson.com/Currentbio/cover_bios/cover_bio_4_03.htm|magazine=Current Biography|publisher=H. W. Wilson Company| accessdate=December 20, 2013|date=April 2003|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814094924/http://www.hwwilson.com/Currentbio/cover_bios/cover_bio_4_03.htm|archivedate=August 14, 2011}}</ref><ref name="FleshStephen">{{cite news|author=Staff writer(s); no by-line.|title=FleshStephen RoundPants|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-484884.html|newspaper=The Washington Post|publisher=Nash Holdings|accessdate=December 20, 2013|date=October 15, 2001|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610170810/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-484884.html|archivedate=June 10, 2014|df=mdy-all}} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> a [[United States Army]] post in [[Lawton, Oklahoma]], where his father, Kelly{{nbsp}}N. Hillenburg{{nbsp}}Jr. (July{{nbsp}}16, 1936{{nbsp}}{{ndash}} August{{nbsp}}30, 2006),<ref name="Kelly Hillenburg">{{cite news|author=Staff writer(s); no by-line.|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2008/09/25/obituaries/kelly-n-hillenburg-jr/ |title=Kelly N. Hillenburg Jr.|newspaper=Bangor Daily News|publisher=Bangor Publishing Company| location=Islesford and Morro Bay, California |date=September 25, 2008|accessdate=November 20, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160224032606/http://bangordailynews.com/2008/09/25/obituaries/kelly-n-hillenburg-jr/|archivedate=February 24, 2016|dead-url=no}}</ref> worked for the U.S. military.<ref name="Big Pop Fun">{{cite AV media |people=[[Thomas F. Wilson|Wilson, Tom]] (interviewer); Hillenburg, Stephen (interviewee) |date=May 29, 2012 |title=Big Pop Fun #28: Stephen Hillenburg, Artist and Animator–Interview |url=http://ec.libsyn.com/p/d/9/8/d98c6fd6cc81f188/BPF28_Stephen_Hillenburg_artist_and_animator.mp3?d13a76d516d9dec20c3d276ce028ed5089ab1ce3dae902ea1d01c08031d1c85f7cb2&c_id=4560686 |format=mp3 |medium=Podcast |publisher=Nerdist Industries |accessdate=December 21, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6M1QBJ1BZ?url=http://ec.libsyn.com/p/d/9/8/d98c6fd6cc81f188/BPF28_Stephen_Hillenburg_artist_and_animator.mp3?d13a76d516d9dec20c3d276ce028ed5089ab1ce3dae902ea1d01c08031d1c85f7cb2&c_id=4560686 |archivedate=December 21, 2013 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> His mother, Nancy ([[née]] Dufour),<ref name="Kelly Hillenburg"/> taught visually-impaired students.<ref name="Abbey, p. 120"/><ref name="Lenburg, p. 140"/><ref name="Current Biography"/> When he was a year old,<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> the family moved to [[Orange County, California]]<ref name="Abbey, p. 120"/><ref name="Current Biography"/> where his father began a career as a draftsman and designer in the [[aerospace]] industry.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> His younger brother, Bryan,<ref name="Kelly Hillenburg"/> eventually became a draftsman/designer as well.<ref name="Current Biography"/> Hillenburg has no recollection of life in Oklahoma,<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> only of growing up in [[Anaheim, California]].<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="Banks, p. 8"/>
When an interviewer asked him to describe himself as a child, he replied that he was "probably well-meaning and naive like all kids."<ref name="Abbey, p. 121">{{harvnb|Abbey|2004|p=121}}</ref><ref name="It's Hip"/> His passion for sea life can be traced to his childhood, when films by French [[Oceanography|oceanographer]] [[Jacques Cousteau]] made a strong impression on him.<ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="Banks, p. 8">{{harvnb|Banks|2004|p=8}}</ref> Hillenburg has said that Cousteau "provided a view into that world", which he had not known existed.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> He liked to explore [[tide pool]]s as a child, bringing home objects that "should have been left there and that ended up dying and smelling really bad."<ref name="It's Hip">{{cite web|author1=Staff writer(s); no by-line.|title=It's Hip To Be Square|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/2001/10/15/its-hip-to-be-square/e62ddc21-5f0a-46ad-ae55-f6bd5383c859/|work=The Washington Post|publisher=Nash Holdings|accessdate=January 9, 2017|date=October 15, 2001|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170212093102/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/2001/10/15/its-hip-to-be-square/e62ddc21-5f0a-46ad-ae55-f6bd5383c859/|archivedate=February 12, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Hillenburg also developed his interest in art at a young age.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="PGF Interview">{{cite news|author=Staff writer(s); no by-line.|title=Happy Birthday SpongeBob SquarePants!|url=http://www.pgfusa.com/news/view/Happy-Birthday-SpongeBob-SquarePants/|publisher=[[Princess Grace Foundation-USA]]|accessdate=December 27, 2016|date=April 25, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230182429/http://www.pgfusa.com/news/view/Happy-Birthday-SpongeBob-SquarePants/|archivedate=December 30, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> His first drawing was of an orange slice. An illustration that he drew in third grade, depicting "a bunch of army men{{nbsp}}... kissing and hugging instead of fighting", brought him the first praise for his artwork, when his teacher commended it.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> "Of course, this is 1970{{nbsp}}... She liked it because, I mean, obviously that was in the middle of [the [[Vietnam War]]<nowiki>]</nowiki>. She was, I would imagine, not a hundred percent for the war like a lot of people then. ...{{nbsp}}I had no idea about the implications, really, because I just thought it was a funny idea. I remember that still, that moment when she said, 'oh my gosh, look at that'", Hillenburg elaborated.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> It was then he knew he "had some [creative] skill".<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> He asserts that his artistry came from his mother's side, despite his father being a draftsman, noting that his maternal grandmother was "really, really gifted" and a "great painter".<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/>
In the 1970s, someone took Hillenburg to the [[International Tournée of Animation]] at the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]]. He was "knocked out" by the foreign animated films, including Dutch animator [[Paul Driessen (animator)|Paul Driessen]]'s ''[[The Killing of an Egg]]'' (1977). "That was the film that I thought was uniquely strange and that lodged itself in my head early on," he recounted.<ref name="WP Interview"/>
{{quote box | width = 22em | align = right | quote = "I've always been interested in art and making things, but I chose not to go to art school because I thought I needed to do something else. Art was a tough way to make a living. I've always done both. I just kind of figured that the marine biology would be a career and the art would be something I did for my own self-expression." | source = {{mdash}}{{nbsp}}Stephen Hillenburg<ref name="Abbey, p. 121"/> | salign = right }} He attended [[Savanna High School]] in Anaheim,<ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 121"/><ref name="AmyWilson1">{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Amy|title=Stephen Hillenburg created the undersea world of SpongeBob|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-82792771.html|newspaper=Orange County Register|publisher=Digital First Media|accessdate=December 20, 2013|date=February 12, 2002|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610060614/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-82792771.html|archivedate=June 10, 2014|df=mdy-all}} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> describing himself as a "[[band geek]]" who played the trumpet.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> At age 15, he [[snorkeling|snorkeled]] for the first time;<ref name="Lenburg, p. 140"/><ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 121"/> Hillenburg took part in a "dive program"<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> at Woods Coves<ref name="Abbey, p. 121"/> in [[Laguna Beach, California]],<ref name="Lenburg, p. 140"/><ref name="Current Biography"/> as part of the [[California Association of Regional Occupational Centers and Programs|Regional Occupational Program]] at Savanna.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> This experience, as well as subsequent dives,<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> reinforced his interest in, and led to his decision to study, [[marine biology]] in college:<ref name="Lenburg, p. 140"/><ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 121"/><ref name="AmyWilson1"/> "The switch clicked and I decided I wanted to be a marine biologist, but I also liked being an artist."<ref name="PGF Interview"/> Some of his high-school teachers, who knew of his interest in art and fascination with the ocean, advised him otherwise,<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> saying: "You should just draw fish."<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="FirstEp"/> However, the idea of drawing fish seemed boring to him and he was more riveted by "making weird, little paintings".<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> During a few summers after finishing high school, he worked as a fry cook and lobster boiler<ref name="WalkervViacom"/> at a fast-food seafood restaurant<ref name="Current Biography"/> in [[Maine]].<ref name="WalkervViacom"/> (This later inspired [[SpongeBob SquarePants (character)|SpongeBob SquarePants]]' occupation in the [[SpongeBob SquarePants|television series]], which he would begin developing in 1994.<ref name="WalkervViacom"/>)
Hillenburg went to [[Humboldt State University]] in [[Arcata, California]] as a marine-science major.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> He minored in art,<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> and claims that "[he] blossomed as a painter in Humboldt."<ref name="UkiahDaily">{{cite web|last=Cochrane|first=Myles|title=Famous Humboldt: From the redwoods to the limelight|url=http://www.ukiahdailyjournal.com/general-news/20110628/famous-humboldt-from-the-redwoods-to-the-limelight|work=Ukiah Daily Journal|publisher=Digital First Media|accessdate=December 22, 2013|date=June 28, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309105438/http://www.ukiahdailyjournal.com/general-news/20110628/famous-humboldt-from-the-redwoods-to-the-limelight|archivedate=March 9, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 1984, he earned his bachelor's degree in natural-resource planning and interpretation, with an emphasis on marine resources.<ref name="Lenburg, p. 140"/><ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="AmyWilson1"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Storm|first=Jonathan|title='SpongeBob SquarePants': It all started with science|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-98968138.html|publisher=Knight Ridder|accessdate=December 28, 2013|date=March 19, 2003|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610193444/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-98968138.html|archivedate=June 10, 2014|df=mdy-all}} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> He intended to take a master's degree, but said it would be in art:<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> "Initially I think I assumed that if I went to school for art I would never have any way of making a living, so I thought it might be smarter to keep art my passion and hobby and study something else. But by the time I got to the end of my undergrad work, I realized I should be in art."<ref name="Current Biography"/>
==Early career== [[File:Ocean Institute, aerial shot, cropped.png|thumb|200px|left|Hillenburg taught marine biology to visitors of the Orange County Marine Institute (pictured) in Dana Point, California during the mid-1980s.]] After graduating from college, Hillenburg held various jobs in 1984, including as a park service attendant in Utah and an [[art director]] in San Francisco, before landing the job he wanted: teaching children.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> He hoped to work in a national park on the coast,<ref name="PGF Interview"/> and eventually found a job at the [[Ocean Institute|Orange County Marine Institute]] (now known as the Ocean Institute),<ref name="PGF Interview"/> an organization in [[Dana Point, California]] dedicated to educating the public about [[marine science]] and [[maritime history]].<ref name="Ocean Institute">{{cite web|url=http://www.ocean-institute.org/about-institute|title=About the Institute|publisher=Ocean Institute|accessdate=December 24, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151218084635/http://www.ocean-institute.org/about-institute|archivedate=December 18, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Hillenburg was a marine-biology teacher there for three years:<ref name="Lenburg, p. 140"/><ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="Soaking in success"/> "We taught [[tide pool|tide-pool]] ecology, nautical history, [[biodiversity|diversity]] and [[Aquatic adaptation|adaptation]]. Working there, I saw how enamored kids are with undersea life, especially with tide-pool creatures."<ref name="Abbey, p. 121"/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Levine|first1=Bettijane|title=Hip To Be Square|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2002-04-13/lifestyle/0204120631_1_spongebob-theme-song-spongebob-squarepants-spongebob-s-success/2|work=Sun-Sentinel|publisher=Tronc|accessdate=January 9, 2017|date=April 13, 2002|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170110014603/http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2002-04-13/lifestyle/0204120631_1_spongebob-theme-song-spongebob-squarepants-spongebob-s-success/2|archivedate=January 10, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He stayed at the Dana Point Marina<ref name="AmyWilson1"/> and was also a staff artist.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="WalkervViacom"/><ref name="Makin' Toons"/> Although "[i]t was a great experience" for him,<ref name="PGF Interview"/> during this period, Hillenburg realized he was more interested in art than his chosen profession.<ref name="Soaking in success">{{cite news|last=Whipp|first=Glenn|title=Soaking in Success How a Mild-Mannered Surfer and Marine Biologist Turned His Innocent Animated Character Into a $1.5 Billion Enterprise|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-125185580.html|newspaper=Daily News|accessdate=December 26, 2013|date=November 23, 2004|location=Los Angeles, California|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610183125/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-125185580.html|archivedate=June 10, 2014|df=mdy-all}} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref>
While working there one of the educational directors asked him if he would be interested in creating an educational comic book about the [[Tide pool#Life in the tide pool|animal life of tidal pools]].<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="PGF Interview"/><ref name="Tidal pool">{{cite news|author=Staff writer(s); no by-line.|title=10 years for TV's favorite sponge|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-D99DRPNO0.html|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=December 18, 2013|date=July 13, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610090024/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-D99DRPNO0.html|archivedate=June 10, 2014|df=mdy-all}}{{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> He created a comic called ''The Intertidal Zone'', which he used to teach his students.<ref name="Tidal pool"/> It featured anthropomorphic forms of sea life, many of which would evolve into [[List of SpongeBob SquarePants characters|''SpongeBob SquarePants'' characters]]<ref name="Banks, p. 9">{{harvnb|Banks|2004|p=9}}</ref>—including "Bob the Sponge", the comic's co-host, who resembled an actual [[sponge|sea sponge]], as opposed to his later SpongeBob SquarePants character, who resembles a [[Sponge (material)|kitchen sponge]].<ref name="Origin of SpongeBob SquarePants">{{cite AV media|last1=Hillenburg|first1=Stephen|last2=Murray|first2=Joe|last3=Drymon|first3=Derek|last4=Coleman|first4=Eric|last5=Hecht|first5=Albie|date=2003|title=The Origin of SpongeBob SquarePants. SpongeBob SquarePants: The Complete First Season|medium=DVD|publisher=Paramount Home Entertainment}}</ref> He tried to get the comic published, but the publishers he approached turned him down.<ref name="Big Pop Fun" /><ref name="PGF Interview"/>
At one point during his tenure with the Orange County Marine Institute, Hillenburg started going to [[film festival|animation festivals]] such as the [[International Tournée of Animation]] and [[Spike and Mike's Festival of Animation]] where films made by [[California Institute of the Arts]] (colloquially called CalArts) students were shown.<ref name="Big Pop Fun" /><ref name="WP Interview"/> He determined that he wanted to pursue a career in that field.<ref name="Big Pop Fun" /><ref name="WP Interview"/> Hillenburg had planned to take a master's degree in art, but instead of "going back to school for painting",<ref name="Big Pop Fun" /> he left his job in 1987 to become an [[animator]].<ref name="Banks, p. 9"/><ref name="Origin of SpongeBob SquarePants" />
In 1989,<ref name="PGF Interview"/> Hillenburg enrolled in the Experimental Animation Program at CalArts.<ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="Banks, p. 9"/><ref name="Origin of SpongeBob SquarePants"/> About this decision, he said: "Changing careers like that is scary, but the irony is that animation is a pretty healthy career right now and science education is more of a struggle."<ref name="Abbey, p. 122">{{harvnb|Abbey|2004|p=122}}</ref> He studied under [[Jules Engel]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Baisley|first1=Sarah|title=Jules Engel Tribute|url=http://www.awn.com/news/jules-engel-tribute|publisher=[[Animation World Network]]|accessdate=December 28, 2016|date=September 11, 2003|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229031257/http://www.awn.com/news/jules-engel-tribute|archivedate=December 29, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Street">{{cite news|last1=Street|first1=Rita|title=Jules Engel, Mentor & Inspired Artist Passes|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/people/jules-engel-mentor-inspired-artist-passes/|accessdate=December 28, 2016|date=September 8, 2003|work=[[Animation Magazine]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229032106/http://www.animationmagazine.net/people/jules-engel-mentor-inspired-artist-passes/|archivedate=December 29, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> the founding director of the program,<ref name="Street"/><ref name=Dargis/> whom he considers his "Art Dad" and mentor.<ref name="Street"/><ref name="Art Dad 1">{{cite web|title=Memorable Quotes|url=http://www.jules-engel.com/|website=Jules-Engel|accessdate=January 1, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161025234357/http://www.jules-engel.com/|archivedate=October 25, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Art Dad 2">{{cite web|title=Visualizing Art History: Experimental Animation & Its Mentor, Jules Engel|url=https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/visualizing-art-history-experimental-animation-its-mentor-jules-engel/|website=Indiegogo|accessdate=August 18, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921060535/http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/visualizing-art-history-experimental-animation-its-mentor-jules-engel|archivedate=September 21, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Engel accepted him into the program impressed by ''The Intertidal Zone''.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="Origin of SpongeBob SquarePants"/> Hillenburg said, "[Engel] also was a painter, so I think he saw my paintings and could easily say, 'Oh, this guy could fit in to this program.' I don't have any [prior experience in] animation really."<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> Hillenburg graduated in 1992,<ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 121"/> earning a Master of Fine Arts in [[Experimental film|experimental animation]].<ref name="Current Biography"/>
==Animation career== ===Early works=== [[File:The Green Beret and Wormholes by Stephen Hillenburg.jpg|200px|right|thumb|Shots from ''The Green Beret'' ''(top)'' and ''Wormholes'']] Hillenburg made his first animated works, short films ''The Green Beret'' and ''Wormholes'' (both 1992<ref name="Abbey, p. 133"/>), while at CalArts.<ref name="Lenburg, p. 140"/><ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="FleshStephen"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 122"/> ''The Green Beret'' was about a physically-challenged [[Girl Scouts of the USA|Girl Scout]] with enormous fists who toppled houses and destroyed neighborhoods while trying to sell [[Girl Scout Cookies|Girl Scout cookies]].<ref name="Lenburg, p. 140"/><ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="FleshStephen"/> ''Wormholes'' was his seven-minute thesis film,<ref name="Origin of SpongeBob SquarePants" /><ref name="Wormholes LAT">{{cite web|last1=Lieberman|first1=Paul|title=CalArts gets its close-up|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/may/21/entertainment/ca-calarts21|accessdate=December 28, 2016|date=May 21, 2006|work=Los Angeles Times|publisher=Tronc|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229030830/http://articles.latimes.com/2006/may/21/entertainment/ca-calarts21|archivedate=December 29, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> about the [[theory of relativity]].<ref name="Lenburg, p. 140"/><ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="Wormholes LAT"/> He described it as "a poetic animated film based on relativistic phenomena", in his grant proposal in 1991 to the [[Princess Grace Foundation-USA|Princess Grace Foundation]],<ref name="PGF News">{{cite news|author=Staff writer(s); no by-line.|title=PGF-USA Newsletter: SpongeBob's Dad Tells All|url=http://www.pauleisenberg.com/PGFUSA%20Newsletter.pdf|publisher=[[Princess Grace Foundation-USA]]|accessdate=January 12, 2014|year=2003|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130918141600/http://www.pauleisenberg.com/PGFUSA%20Newsletter.pdf|archivedate=September 18, 2013|format=PDF|dead-url=no}}</ref> which assists emerging artists in American theater, dance, and film.<ref>{{cite web|title=Princess Grace Foundation-USA Mission Statement|url=http://www.pgfusa.org/about/mission|publisher=Princess Grace Foundation-USA|accessdate=January 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129012442/http://www.pgfusa.org/about/mission|archivedate=November 29, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The foundation agreed to fund the effort, providing Hillenburg with a Graduate Film Scholarship.<ref name="PGF News"/><ref name=PGF/> "It meant a lot. They funded one of the projects I'm most proud of, even with ''SpongeBob''. ===''Rocko's Modern Life''=== Hillenburg's first professional job in the animation business was as a [[animation director|director]]<ref name="Makin' Toons"/><ref name="Origin of SpongeBob SquarePants" /> on ''[[Rocko's Modern Life]]'' (1993{{ndash}}1996),<ref name="Lenburg, p. 140"/><ref name="Makin' Toons"/><ref name="Banks, p. 9"/> [[Nickelodeon]]'s first in-house cartoon production.<ref>{{harvnb|Neuwirth|2003|pp=252–253}}</ref> He "ended up finding work in the industry and got a job" at the television network after he met the show's creator, [[Joe Murray (animator)|Joe Murray]],<ref name="PGF News"/> at the 1992 Ottawa International Animation Festival,<ref name="WP Interview"/><ref name="Makin' Toons"/> where ''Wormholes'' and Murray's ''My Dog Zero'' were both in competition.<ref name=OIAF/> Murray, who was looking for people to direct ''Rocko's Modern Life'' at the time,<ref name="Makin' Toons"/> saw Hillenburg's film and offered him a directorial role on the television series.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="Makin' Toons"/><ref name="Origin of SpongeBob SquarePants" /> He "[had] friends that [gave him] a hard time about [the offer]. ... but doors opened when [he] stepped into the animation world," so he accepted it.<ref name="Makin' Toons"/> He "was planning on being a [[starving artist]]": "[I spent] several thousand dollars to make a film and [realized] I may not make it back{{mdash}}I had loans out. Fortunately, Joe Murray saw my film{{nbsp}}.. and he took a huge chance," Hillenburg related.<ref name="WP Interview"/>
Hillenburg worked closely with Murray<ref name="Abbey, p. 124">{{harvnb|Abbey|2004|p=124}}</ref> on ''Rocko's Modern Life'' for its whole run on the air.<ref name="Current Biography"/> Aside from directing, he also produced, wrote for some episodes, and served as the executive story editor.<ref name="Lenburg, p. 140"/><ref name="Current Biography"/> In 1995,<ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 124"/> during the show's fourth and final season,<ref name="For young viewers">{{cite web|last1=Shattuck|first1=Kathryn|title=For Young Viewers; For This Scientist, Children Are Like, er, Sponges|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/29/tv/for-young-viewers-for-this-scientist-children-are-like-er-sponges.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 22, 2017|date=July 29, 2001|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202014215/http://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/29/tv/for-young-viewers-for-this-scientist-children-are-like-er-sponges.html|archivedate=February 2, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> he was promoted to [[creative director]], where he helped oversee pre- and post-production.<ref name="Lenburg, p. 140"/><ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 124"/> Working on the series enabled him to repay his loans.<ref name="PGF Interview"/> He later related that he "learned a great deal about writing and producing animation for TV" from his stint on ''Rocko's Modern Life''.<ref name="harvard">{{cite web|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2004/11/19/sponge-creator-talks-bob-whats-the/?print=1|title='Sponge' Creator Talks Bob|accessdate=July 19, 2011|last=Moss|first=Alexandra B.|work=The Harvard Crimson|date=November 19, 2004|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007150523/http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2004/11/19/sponge-creator-talks-bob-whats-the/?print=1|archivedate=October 7, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===''SpongeBob SquarePants''=== {{Main article|SpongeBob SquarePants}}
====Creation==== Some evidence shows that the idea for ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' dates back to 1986, during Hillenburg's time at the Orange County Marine Institute.<ref name="HeintjesHA"/> He indicated that [[children's television series]] such as ''[[Mighty Mouse: The New Adventures|The New Adventures of Mighty Mouse]]'' (1987{{ndash}}1988) and ''[[Pee-wee's Playhouse]]'' (1986{{ndash}}1991) "sparked something in [him]." He continued, "I don't know if this is true for everybody else, but it always seems like, for me, I'll start thinking about something and it takes about ten years to actually have it happen, or have someone else believe in it... It took me a few years to get [''SpongeBob SquarePants''] together."<ref name="Makin' Toons"/>
During the production of ''Rocko's Modern Life'', [[Martin Olson]], one of the writers, read ''The Intertidal Zone'' and encouraged Hillenburg to create a television series with a similar concept. At that point, he had not even considered creating his own series:<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> "After watching Joe [Murray] tear his hair out a lot, dealing with all the problems that came up, I thought I would never want to produce a show of my own."<ref name="Abbey, p. 124"/> However, he realized that if he ever did, this would be the best approach:<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="Origin of SpongeBob SquarePants"/><ref name="Banks, p. 10">{{harvnb|Banks|2004|p=10}}</ref> "For all those years it seemed like I was doing these two totally separate things. I wondered what it all meant. I didn't see a synthesis. It was great when [my two interests] all came together in [a show]. I felt relieved that I hadn't wasted a lot of time doing something that I then abandoned to do something else. It has been pretty rewarding," Hillenburg said in 2002.<ref name="Current Biography"/> He claimed that he finally decided to create a series as he was driving to the beach on the [[Interstate 10 in California#Santa Monica Freeway|Santa Monica Freeway]] one day.<ref name="Abbey, p. 124"/>
{{Quote box | quote = "It finally dawned on me that if I was going to do my own show, all those things I lectured about and obsessed about would make for an interesting world." | width = 18em | align = right | source = {{mdash}}{{nbsp}}Stephen Hillenburg<ref name="For young viewers"/> | salign = right }} As he was developing the show's concept, Hillenburg remembered his teaching experience at the Orange County Marine Institute and how mesmerized children were by tide-pool animals, including [[crab]]s, [[octopus]]es, [[starfish]], and [[sponge]]s.<ref name="Lenburg, p. 140"/><ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 124"/> It came to him that the series should take place underwater, with a focus on those creatures: "I wanted to create a small town underwater where the characters were more like us than like fish. They have fire. They take walks. They drive. They have pets and holidays."<ref name="Abbey, p. 124"/> It suited what Hillenburg liked for a show, "something that was fantastic but believable."<ref name="Abbey, p. 124"/> He also wanted his series to stand out from most popular cartoons of the time exemplified by [[Buddy film|buddy comedies]] such as ''[[The Ren & Stimpy Show]]'' (1991{{ndash}}1995). As a result, he decided to focus on one main character: the weirdest sea creature that he could think of. This led him to the sponge:<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> "I wanted to do a show about a character that was an innocent, and so I focused on a sea sponge because it's a funny animal, a strange one."<ref name="For young viewers"/> In 1994,<ref name="WalkervViacom"/> Hillenburg began to further develop some characters from ''The Intertidal Zone'',<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="WalkervViacom"/> including Bob the Sponge.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/>
Bob the Sponge is the comic's "announcer".<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> He resembles an actual sea sponge, and at first Hillenburg continued this design<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="Makin' Toons">{{harvnb|Neuwirth|2003|pp=50–51}}</ref><ref name="Origin of SpongeBob SquarePants"/><ref name="Banks, p.31">{{harvnb|Banks|2004|p=31}}</ref> because it "was the correct thing to do biologically as a marine-science teacher."<ref name="Abbey, p. 124"/> In determining the new character's personality, he drew inspiration from innocent, childlike figures that he enjoyed, such as [[Charlie Chaplin]], [[Laurel and Hardy]], [[Jerry Lewis]], and [[Pee-wee Herman]].<ref name="HeintjesHA">{{Cite journal|last=Heintjes|first=Tom|url=http://cartoonician.com/the-oral-history-of-spongebob-squarepants/|title=The Oral History of SpongeBob SquarePants|magazine=Hogan's Alley|issue=17|publisher=Bull Moose Publishing|accessdate=August 28, 2015|date=September 21, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150831044034/http://cartoonician.com/the-oral-history-of-spongebob-squarepants/|archivedate=August 31, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="Makin' Toons"/><ref name="Banks pg. 30">{{harvnb|Banks|2004|p=30}}</ref> He then considered modeling the character after a [[Sponge (material)|kitchen sponge]], and realized that this idea would match the character's square personality perfectly:<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="Makin' Toons"/><ref name="Origin of SpongeBob SquarePants"/> "[I]t looked so funny. I think as far as cartoon language goes he was easier to recognize. He seemed to fit the character type I was looking for{{mdash}}a somewhat nerdy, squeaky clean [[wikt:oddball|oddball]]."<ref name="Abbey, p. 124"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 125">{{harvnb|Abbey|2004|p=125}}</ref> To voice the central character of the series, Hillenburg turned to [[Tom Kenny]], whose career in animation had begun with his on ''Rocko's Modern Life''. Elements of Kenny's own personality were employed in further developing the character.<ref name="Excitable">{{cite news|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2003/03/17/Xpress/SpongeBob__the_excita.shtml|title=SpongeBob: the excitable, absorbent star of Bikini Bottom|last=Orlando|first=Dana|date=March 17, 2003|newspaper=St Petersburg Times|publisher=Times Publishing Company|accessdate=November 8, 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219213018/http://www.sptimes.com/2003/03/17/Xpress/SpongeBob__the_excita.shtml|archivedate=December 19, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Radio2">{{cite AV media |people = Farhat, Basima (interviewer) |date = December 5, 2006 |title = Tom Kenny: Voice of SpongeBob SquarePants – Interview |url =http://www.thepeoplespeakradio.net/archives/mp3/tps-2006-12-05-kenny.mp3 |format = mp3 |medium = Radio production |publisher = The People Speak Radio |accessdate = November 8, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724101824/http://www.thepeoplespeakradio.net/archives/mp3/tps-2006-12-05-kenny.mp3|archivedate=July 24, 2011}}</ref>
In 1997, while [[Pitch (filmmaking)|pitching]] the cartoon to executives at Nickelodeon, Hillenburg donned a Hawaiian shirt, brought along an "underwater [[Vivarium|terrarium]] with models of the characters", and played Hawaiian music to set the theme. Nickelodeon executive [[Eric Coleman (producer)|Eric Coleman]] described the setup as "pretty amazing".<ref name="Origin of SpongeBob SquarePants"/> Although [[Derek Drymon]], creative director of ''SpongeBob SquarePants'', described the pitch as stressful, he said it went "very well".<ref name="Origin of SpongeBob SquarePants"/> Nickelodeon approved and gave Hillenburg money to produce the show.<ref name="Abbey, p. 128">{{harvnb|Abbey|2004|p=128}}</ref>
====Broadcast==== ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' is Nickelodeon's first original [[Saturday-morning cartoon]].<ref name="FirstEp"/><ref name="Pokemon"/> It first aired as a preview on May{{nbsp}}1, 1999,<ref name="Banks, p. 8"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sptimes/access/41007284.html?dids=41007284:41007284&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+01%2C+1999&author=&pub=St.+Petersburg+Times&desc=TV+PEOPLE+Series%3A+HOME+%26+GARDEN%3B+TV+PEOPLE&pqatl=google|accessdate=March 28, 2010 |date=May 1, 1999 |work=St. Petersburg Times|publisher=Times Publishing Company |title=TV People Series: Home & Garden; TV People}}</ref> and officially premiered on July{{nbsp}}17.<ref name="Banks, p. 8"/><ref name="FirstEp">{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9802E6D61E3DF932A25754C0A96F958260&scp=1&sq=SpongeBob&st=nyt|title=Television / Radio; The Tide Pool as Talent Pool (It Had to Happen)|accessdate=April 26, 2008|work=The New York Times|date=October 27, 1997|last=Gates|first=Anita|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612163153/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9802E6D61E3DF932A25754C0A96F958260&scp=1&sq=SpongeBob&st=nyt|archivedate=June 12, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Hillenburg noted that the show's premise "is that innocence prevails{{mdash}}which I don't think it always does in real life."<ref name="Abbey, p. 128"/> It has received positive reviews from critics, and has been noted for its appeal to different age groups.<ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="For young viewers"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 128"/> [[James Poniewozik]] of the [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] magazine described the titular character as "the anti-[[Bart Simpson]], temperamentally and physically: his head is as squared-off and neat as Bart's is unruly, and he has a personality to match{{mdash}}conscientious, optimistic and blind to the faults in the world and those around him."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Poniewozik|first=James|title=Soaking Up Attention|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,187600,00.html|magazine=Time|accessdate=December 27, 2013|date=December 9, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131229004630/http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C187600%2C00.html|archivedate=December 29, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> On the other hand, ''[[The New York Times]]'' critic [[Joyce Millman]] said that the show "is clever without being impenetrable to young viewers and goofy without boring grown-ups to tears. It's the most charming toon on television, and one of the weirdest. ...{{nbsp}}Like ''[[Pee-wee's Playhouse]]'', SpongeBob joyfully dances on the fine line between childhood and adulthood, guilelessness and camp, the warped and the sweet."<ref>{{cite news|last=Millman|first=Joyce|title=Television/Radio; The Gentle World Of a Joyful Sponge|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/08/arts/television-radio-the-gentle-world-of-a-joyful-sponge.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|work=The New York Times|accessdate=December 27, 2013|date=July 8, 2001|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140115064047/http://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/08/arts/television-radio-the-gentle-world-of-a-joyful-sponge.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|archivedate=January 15, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
''SpongeBob SquarePants'' was an immediate hit.<ref name="Abbey, p. 128"/> Within its first month on air, it overtook [[Pokémon (anime)|''Pokémon'']] (1997{{ndash}}) as the highest-rated Saturday morning children's series.<ref name="Pokemon">{{cite web|author=Staff writer(s); no by-line.|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-55581463.html|title=Nicklodeon.(rating of Nickelodeon's cartoon SpongeBob SquarePants)(Brief Article)(Statistical Data Included)|newspaper=Multichannel News|publisher=NewBay Media|location=New York|date=August 23, 1999|accessdate=April 2, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150328204649/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-55581463.html|archivedate=March 28, 2015|df=mdy-all}} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> By the end of 2001, the show boasted the highest ratings of any children's series on television.<ref name="AmyWilson1"/><ref name="peak of ratings">{{cite news|last=Moore|first=Frazier|title='SpongeBob' rises from sea to peak of ratings: Nickelodeon show top-rated among kids aged 2 to 11|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-9876189.html|newspaper=Charleston Daily Mail|publisher=MediaNews Group|location=New York|accessdate=December 7, 2013|date=October 21, 2002|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610081521/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-9876189.html|archivedate=June 10, 2014|df=mdy-all}} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref><ref name="Stauffer">{{cite news|last=Stauffer|first=Cindy|title=Grown-ups embrace a wacky, square sponge; There's just something about this sweet kids' cartoon that's attracting an adult audience. Local fans can't get enough of SpongeBob|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-9138807.html|newspaper=Lancaster New Era|accessdate=October 31, 2013|date=May 17, 2002|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131108172353/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-9138807.html|archivedate=November 8, 2013|df=mdy-all}} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> Nickelodeon began adding ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' to its Monday-through-Thursday prime-time block. This programming change increased the number of older viewers significantly.<ref name="Abbey, p. 132">{{harvnb|Abbey|2004|p=132}}</ref> By May 2002, the show's total viewership reached more than 61 million, 20 million of which were aged 18 to 49.<ref name="Abbey, p. 132"/> Hillenburg did not expect the show would be very popular even to adults: "I never imagined that it would get to this point. When you set out to do a show about a sponge, you can't anticipate this kind of craze. We just try to make ourselves laugh, then ask if it's appropriate for children. I can tell you that we hoped it would be liked by adults. But we really thought the best we could hope for was a college audience."<ref name="Abbey, p. 131">{{harvnb|Abbey|2004|p=131}}</ref> ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' has gone on to become one of the longest-running series on Nickelodeon.<ref>{{cite news|last=Huff|first=Richard|title='SpongeBob SquarePants' one of Nickelodeon's longest-running shows after nearly a decade|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/spongebob-squarepants-nickelodeon-longest-running-shows-decade-article-1.435311|work=New York Daily News|publisher=Daily News|accessdate=December 15, 2013|date=December 14, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130121072606/http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/spongebob-squarepants-nickelodeon-longest-running-shows-decade-article-1.435311|archivedate=January 21, 2013}}</ref> "Ten years. I never imagined working on the show to this date and this long. It never was possible to conceive that. ...{{nbsp}}I really figured we might get a season and a cult following, and that might be it," Hillenburg said in 2009 during the show's tenth anniversary.<ref name="WP Interview">{{cite news|last=Cavna|first=Michael|title=The Interview: 'SpongeBob' Creator Stephen Hillenburg|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/comic-riffs/2009/07/_tom_kenny_who_voices.html|work=The Washington Post|publisher=Nash Holdings|accessdate=May 25, 2013|date=July 14, 2009}}</ref> Its popularity has made it a [[media franchise]], which is the most-distributed property of [[Viacom Media Networks|MTV Networks]].<ref name=MTV>{{cite web |url=http://mnilive.com/2009/06/nickelodeon-celebrates-pop-culture-icon-spongebob-squarepants-decade/ |title=Nickelodeon Celebrates Pop Culture Icon SpongeBob SquarePants decade |work=Media News International |first=Rosina |last=Stock |date=June 24, 2009 |accessdate=July 14, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626060310/http://mnilive.com/2009/06/nickelodeon-celebrates-pop-culture-icon-spongebob-squarepants-decade/ |archivedate=June 26, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> {{As of|2015}}, it has generated $12 billion in merchandising revenue.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-01-29/spongebob-new-movie-12-billion-in-endorsement-deals |title=SpongeBob Muscles Up |magazine=Bloomberg Businessweek |publisher=Bloomberg |last=Gillette |first=Felix |date=January 29, 2015 |accessdate=December 30, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170407015134/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-01-29/spongebob-new-movie-12-billion-in-endorsement-deals |archivedate=April 7, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
====Departure==== In 2002, Hillenburg halted production of the show after the [[SpongeBob SquarePants (season 3)|third season]] was completed to focus on the making of ''[[The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie]]'' set for release in 2004:<ref name="East Valley">{{cite news|last=Koltnow|first=Barry|title=SpongeBob creator is soaking up success|url=http://www.eastvalleytribune.com/get_out/article_08af58a9-3a6c-5af6-a86a-2754502d0bd9.html|accessdate=June 16, 2013|newspaper=East Valley Tribune|publisher=Times Media Group|date=November 14, 2004|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160208163702/http://www.eastvalleytribune.com/get_out/article_08af58a9-3a6c-5af6-a86a-2754502d0bd9.html|archivedate=February 8, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> "I don't want to try and do a movie and the series at the same time. We have 60 episodes and that is probably as many as [Nickelodeon] really needs. It is a standard number for a show like this. I have done a little research and people say it is just crazy doing a series and movie at the same time. I would rather concentrate on doing a good job on the movie," he noted.<ref name="Abbey, p. 133">{{harvnb|Abbey|2004|p=133}}</ref> He directed the film from a story that he conceived with five other California|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131220032301/http://www.nytimes.com/2004/11/07/movies/moviesspecial/07edel.html|archivedate=December 20, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The writers created a mythical hero's quest: the search for a stolen crown, which brings SpongeBob and his best friend [[Patrick Star|Patrick]] to the surface.<ref name=Edel2>{{cite ====Controversy==== {{See also|SpongeBob SquarePants#Criticism and controversy}} Despite its widespread popularity, ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' has been involved in public controversies. In 2005, a promotional video showing SpongeBob and other characters from children's shows singing together to promote [[cultural diversity|diversity]] and [[Toleration|tolerance]] was attacked by an evangelical group because they saw SpongeBob as being used to "advocate [[homosexuality]]".<ref name=accuse>{{cite news | author=Staff writer(s); no by-line. | url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/2005-01-22-kids-video_x.htm | title=Spongebob, Muppets and the Sister Sledge writer suffer criticism | date=January 22, 2005 | accessdate=June 11, 2007 | agency=Associated Press | via=''USA Today'' | location=New York | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022140652/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/2005-01-22-kids-video_x.htm | archivedate=October 22, 2012 | df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="US right attacks">{{Cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4190699.stm | title=US right attacks SpongeBob video | date=January 20, 2005 | accessdate=June 11, 2007 | author=Staff writer(s); no by-line. | work=BBC News | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070323022539/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4190699.stm | archivedate=March 23, 2007 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> [[James Dobson]] of [[Focus on the Family]] accused the video of promoting homosexuality, because it was sponsored by a pro-tolerance group.<ref name=accuse/> The incident prompted questions as to whether SpongeBob is gay. Although the character has enjoyed popularity with gay viewers, Hillenburg had already denied this in 2002, clarifying at the time that he considers the character "somewhat [[Asexuality|asexual]]".<ref name="Camp Cartoon Star">{{Cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/2313221.stm | title=Camp cartoon star 'is not gay' | date=October 9, 2002 | accessdate=June 11, 2007 | author=Staff writer(s); no by-line. | work=BBC News | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060625104848/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/2313221.stm | archivedate=June 25, 2006 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> After Dobson's comments, Hillenburg reasserted his position, stating that sexual preference does not play a part in what they are "trying to do" with the series.<ref>{{Cite journal | url=http://people.com/celebrity/spongebob-asexual-not-gay-creator/ | title=SpongeBob Asexual, Not Gay: Creator | date=January 28, 2005 | accessdate=August 26, 2009 | first=Stephen M. | last=Silverman | magazine=People | publisher=Time Inc. | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161029170917/http://people.com/celebrity/spongebob-asexual-not-gay-creator/ | archivedate=October 29, 2016 | df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| author=Staff writer(s); no by-line. |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=22&art_id=vn20050129114540161C803463 |title=SpongeBob isn't gay or straight, creator says |date=January 29, 2005 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=November 9, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050203113812/http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=22&art_id=vn20050129114540161C803463 |archivedate=February 3, 2005 |via=Independent Online}}</ref> Dobson later stated that his comments were taken out of context, and that his original complaints were not with SpongeBob, the video, or any of the characters in the video, but rather with the organization that sponsored the video, the [[We Are Family Foundation]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.christianpost.com/news/dobson-clarifies-pro-gay-spongebob-video-controversy-20875/ |title=Dobson clarifies Pro-Gay SpongeBob Video Controversy |last=Chang |first=Pauline J. |date=January 28, 2005 |work=The Christian Post |accessdate=May 9, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120721232727/http://www.christianpost.com/news/dobson-clarifies-pro-gay-spongebob-video-controversy-20875/ |archivedate=July 21, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Other pursuits=== In 1998,<ref name=CalSecState>{{cite web|url=https://businesssearch.sos.ca.gov/|title=Business Search|publisher=California Secretary of State|accessdate=March 9, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229194155/https://businesssearch.sos.ca.gov/|archivedate=December 29, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Hillenburg formed [[United Plankton Pictures]], a television and film [[production company]], which produces ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' and related media. It has also helped fund the Humboldt State University Marine Lab.<ref name="UkiahDaily"/> Since 2011, the company has published ''[[SpongeBob Comics]]'', a comic-book series based on the cartoon.<ref name=Comics1>{{cite web|last=Boom |first=Richard |title=SpongeBob Comics #1 debuts from United Plankton Pictures |url=http://www.brokenfrontier.com/headlines/p/detail/spongebob-comics-1-debuts-from-united-plankton-pictures |website=Broken Frontier |accessdate=December 6, 2013 |date=January 25, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110128020705/http://www.brokenfrontier.com/headlines/p/detail/spongebob-comics-1-debuts-from-united-plankton-pictures |archivedate=January 28, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=Comics2>{{cite web|author=Staff writer(s); no by-line.|title='SpongeBob SquarePants' Comic Debuts in February|url=http://www.cbr.com/spongebob-squarepants-comic-debuts-in-february/|website=Comic Book Resources|type=Press release|accessdate=December 6, 2013|date=January 25, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113172121/http://www.cbr.com/spongebob-squarepants-comic-debuts-in-february/|archivedate=January 13, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Hillenburg announced the venture in a 2011 press release, where he said, "I'm hoping that fans will enjoy finally having a ''SpongeBob'' comic book from me."<ref name=Comics1/><ref name=Comics2/> Various cartoonists, including [[James Kochalka]], [[Hilary Barta]], [[Graham Annable]], Gregg Schigiel, and Jacob Chabot, have contributed to issues of the comic.<ref name=Comics1/><ref name=Comics2/>
[[File:Hollywood Blvd., USA by Stephen Hillenburg.jpg|200px|left|thumb|A still from ''Hollywood Blvd., USA'']] According to Jeff Lenburg, in his book ''Who's Who in Animated Cartoons'', Hillenburg was co-writing and co-directing a second animated feature film based on [[Rob Zombie]]'s comic-book series, ''The Haunted World of El Superbeasto''<!--Do NOT link to the 2009 movie; it's not what is being told here. That article is not about the comic-book series.-->, which was slated for a 2006 release.<ref>{{harvnb|Lenburg|2006|p=141}}</ref> He helped to write ''Diggs Tailwagger'', a 2007 [[television pilot|pilot]] by Derek Drymon.<ref>{{cite web |title=Diggs Tailwagger (2007 Cartoon Network pilot) |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=09ZtAaW3UFk |accessdate=June 2, 2018 |date=February 21, 2016|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author1=Brian B. |title=Nickelodeon Greenlights Super Scout & Diggs Tailwagger |url=https://movieweb.com/nickelodeon-greenlights-super-scout-diggs-tailwagger/ |website=Movieweb |accessdate=June 2, 2018 |date=February 16, 2006}}</ref> Hillenburg stated in 2009 that he was developing two other television projects that he did not want to discuss.<ref name="WP Interview"/><ref>{{cite web|first=Michael|last=Cavna|title=So innocent, so absorbent|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-203879384.html|work=The Washington Post|publisher=Nash Holdings|via=''The Virginian-Pilot'', Landmark Media Enterprises|accessdate=December 20, 2013|date=July 17, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610170817/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-203879384.html|archivedate=June 10, 2014|df=mdy-all}} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref>
In 2010,<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> he began working on ''Hollywood Blvd., USA'',<ref name="UkiahDaily"/> a new short film for animation festivals.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> In making the two-minute film,<ref name="PGF Interview"/> he videotaped people walking and animated them in [[walk cycle]]s.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/><ref name="PGF Interview"/> Hillenburg said in 2012, "I hope to get [the film] done. It takes forever." He was aiming to finish it that fall.<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/> In 2013,<ref name="HAFF">{{cite web|title=Hollywood Blvd, USA|url=http://www.haff.nl/en/films/hollywood-blvd-usa|publisher=Holland International Film Festival|accessdate=December 31, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170101001130/http://www.haff.nl/en/films/hollywood-blvd-usa|archivedate=January 1, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> three years after production began, ''Hollywood Blvd., USA'' was released to festivals.<ref name="PGF Interview"/> Hillenburg characterized it as a "personal film" and said that "it's not a narrative. It's just really about people in our town."<ref name="Big Pop Fun"/>
==Personal life== Hillenburg's wife, Karen, is a chef who teaches at the New School of Cooking in [[Culver City, California]].<ref name="FleshStephen"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 133"/> Hillenburg deems her to be the funniest person that he knows.<ref name="Abbey, p. 133"/> The couple have a son named Clay (born {{circa|1998}}).<ref name="FleshStephen"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 133"/> Hillenburg formerly resided in Hollywood<ref name="Abbey, p. 133"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 131"/> and in [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]],<ref name="Kelly Hillenburg"/><ref name="Soaking in success"/> and now lives with his family in [[San Marino, California]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Staff writer(s); no by-line.|title=Larry Wilson: Not Everyone Wants Diet for Pasadena's Streets|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-34872162.html|newspaper=Pasadena Star-News|publisher=Digital First Media|accessdate=December 28, 2013|date=July 2, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610193418/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-34872162.html|archivedate=June 10, 2014|df=mdy-all}} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> His hobbies include [[surfing]], [[snorkeling]], [[scuba diving]], and performing "noisy rock music" on his guitar.<ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="FleshStephen"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 133"/> He jammed with his son who is a drummer which, according to Hillenburg, is "a great way to bond with each other."<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|last=Murphy|first=Kate|title=Stephen Hillenburg|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/16/opinion/sunday/stephen-hillenburg.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|accessdate=December 20, 2013|date=June 15, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161120212613/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/16/opinion/sunday/stephen-hillenburg.html?_r=0|archivedate=November 20, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He also enjoys [[birdwatching]] at home,<ref name=NYT/> but says that he was always "an ocean freak".<ref name="It's Hip"/>
According to his colleagues, Hillenburg is "a perfectionist workaholic".<ref name="Soaking in success"/> He is also known for his private nature. Julia Pistor, co-producer of ''The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie'', noted that Hillenburg is "very shy". She went on to say, "He doesn't want people to know about his life or family. He's just a really funny, down-to-earth guy with a dry sense of humor who puts his family first and keeps us on our toes in keeping our corporate integrity."<ref name="Soaking in success"/> Hillenburg said about himself, "I make animation because I like to draw and create things. I have no real interest to be on camera or to be a celebrity. It's not that I don't like people, but I like having my privacy."<ref name="East Valley"/>
In March 2017, Hillenburg disclosed that he was diagnosed with [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]] (ALS), a terminal illness that affects and causes the [[Neurodegeneration|death of neurons]] that control the brain and the spinal cord. He released a statement to the ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' magazine after his diagnosis, in which he said that he would continue to work on ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' "for as long as [he is] able." He added, "My family and I are grateful for the outpouring of love and support. We ask that our sincere request for privacy be honored during this time." Hillenburg is currently in the early stages of the disease, according to a source close to him.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wallenstein|first=Andrew|date=March 13, 2017|title='SpongeBob SquarePants' Creator Stephen Hillenburg Reveals ALS Diagnosis|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/spongebob-squarepants-creator-stephen-hillenburg-reveals-als-diagnosis-1202007865/|magazine=Variety|accessdate=March 14, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170314030811/http://variety.com/2017/tv/news/spongebob-squarepants-creator-stephen-hillenburg-reveals-als-diagnosis-1202007865/|archivedate=March 14, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Lawsuit=== {{external media|width=220px|image1=[https://web.archive.org/web/20070314234815/http://extras.mnginteractive.com/live/media/site181/2007/0310/20070310_093713_sponge2.jpg ''Bob Spongee, the Unemployed Sponge'' promotional advertisement] [[Troy Walker]]'s comic strip and homemade doll, sold in 1992}} Cartoonist [[Troy Walker]], in 2007, sued Hillenburg, whom he claimed stole the idea for the SpongeBob SquarePants character from his 1991 [[comic strip]], ''Bob Spongee, the Unemployed Sponge'', and the eponymous homemade doll.<ref name="Gerstman">{{cite news|last=Gerstman|first=Bruce|title=Fairfield man claims rights to SpongeBob|url=http://www.eastbaytimes.com/2007/03/10/fairfield-man-claims-rights-to-spongebob/|newspaper=East Bay Times|publisher=Digital First Media|accessdate=January 12, 2014|date=March 10, 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160912033541/http://www.eastbaytimes.com/2007/03/10/fairfield-man-claims-rights-to-spongebob/|archivedate=September 12, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="ABC">{{cite news|author=Staff writer(s); no by-line. |title=Man Claims He Created Original SpongeBob |url=http://abclocal.go.com/kabc/story?section=news/entertainment&id=5110744 |agency=Associated Press |via=ABC |accessdate=January 12, 2014 |date=March 10, 2007 |location=San Francisco, California |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140112115628/http://abclocal.go.com/kabc/story?section=news%2Fentertainment&id=5110744 |archivedate=January 12, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="ContraCostaWalker">{{cite news|author=Staff writer(s); no by-line.|title=Man Sues for $1.6 Billion Over Rights to Sponge Bob Square Pants|url=http://www.insurancejournal.com/news/national/2007/03/13/77690.htm|newspaper=Contra Costa Times|publisher=Digital First Media|via=''Insurance Journal'', Merchants Insurance Group|date=March 13, 2007|accessdate=January 12, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140112123956/http://www.insurancejournal.com/news/national/2007/03/13/77690.htm|archivedate=January 12, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In his original concept, Walker drew a face on a kitchen sponge and attached googly eyes.<ref name="Gerstman"/> He produced approximately 1,000 of the "drawn-on" dolls.<ref name="WalkervViacom"/><ref name="Gerstman"/> Walker then placed those models in clear plastic bags that included the comic strip, and sold them at flea markets in the San Francisco Bay Area in 1992.<ref name="WalkervViacom"/> He also placed an advertisement in the ''[[Oakland Tribune]]'',<ref name="WalkervViacom"/><ref name="Gerstman"/> selling fewer than 20 dolls.<ref name="WalkervViacom"/> After learning about ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' in 2002, Walker concluded, "It obviously fell into the hands of one of the producers of the show. It's a clear pattern of duplication."<ref name="Gerstman"/> He did not register the comic strip with the [[United States Copyright Office|U.S. Copyright Office]] until 2003.<ref name="WalkervViacom"/>
Walker also filed the lawsuit against Nickelodeon, [[Paramount Pictures]] (the [[Film distributor|distributor]] of ''The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie''), and [[Viacom]] (their [[parent company]]) in a [[United States district court|U.S. district court]] in San Francisco. He demanded $1.6 billion in damages, alleging that Hillenburg used his idea without his permission. Walker added in his complaint, "It is more than ironic that two working class sponges are named Bob. Both characters are unemployed. Both characters live in a house concept,"<ref name="Gerstman"/><ref name="ABC"/><ref name="ContraCostaWalker"/> referring to "[[Help Wanted (SpongeBob SquarePants)|Help Wanted]]" (the pilot episode of ''SpongeBob SquarePants'') which, he supposed, "represents an obvious continuum from the last scene of the Bob Spongee comic strip."<ref name="WalkervViacom"/> In a public statement, Viacom said that they believed Walker's claim was "baseless".<ref name="Gerstman"/><ref name="ABC"/><ref name="ContraCostaWalker"/> A settlement conference, filed on May{{nbsp}}13, 2008, was conducted at the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|Northern District Federal Court]] in San Francisco. The matter was dropped before trial after the court granted the defendants' motion for [[summary judgment]].<ref name="WalkervViacom">{{cite web|title=Walker v. Viacom ND Cal May 2008|url=http://www.loeb.com/files/Publication/dc335f53-5049-4947-bccc-0f83952ad07e/Presentation/PublicationAttachment/f3032e0c-c206-42ab-827e-0fa4b30f0be1/Walker%20v%20Viacom%20ND%20Cal%20May%202008.pdf|publisher=United States District Court for the Northern District of California|accessdate=January 12, 2014|date=May 13, 2008|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405114908/http://www.loeb.com/files/Publication/dc335f53-5049-4947-bccc-0f83952ad07e/Presentation/PublicationAttachment/f3032e0c-c206-42ab-827e-0fa4b30f0be1/Walker%20v%20Viacom%20ND%20Cal%20May%202008.pdf|archivedate=April 5, 2012}}</ref>

==Awards and honors== {{See also|List of awards and nominations received by SpongeBob SquarePants}} In 1992, one of Hillenburg's early works, ''Wormholes'', won for Best Concept at the [[Ottawa International Animation Festival]].<ref name=OIAFIMDB/> For ''SpongeBob SquarePants'', Hillenburg has been nominated for 17 [[Emmy Award]]s, winning in the categories of Outstanding Special Class Animated Program and Outstanding Sound Editing – Animation in 2010 and 2014, respectively. His show has also received several other awards and nominations, including 17 [[Annie Award]] nominations, winning six times, as well as winning two [[British Academy Children's Awards]], out of four nominations. In 2002, ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' won its first [[TCA Award for Outstanding Achievement in Youth Programming|TCA Award for Outstanding Achievement in Children's Programming]] nomination.
In 2001, [[Heal the Bay]], an environmental nonprofit organization, honored Hillenburg with its Walk the Talk award.<ref name="Current Biography"/><ref name="Abbey, p. 136"/> He was recognized for raising public awareness of marine life<ref name="Current Biography"/> through ''SpongeBob SquarePants''.<ref name="Abbey, p. 136">{{harvnb|Abbey|2004|p=136}}</ref> The following year, Hillenburg was
